Award.AwardTitle: OP: Establishing the Crystallochemical Principles Governing Energy-Transfer Processes in Upconversion Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical description: There is a strong need for bright and multicolor optical probes for biophotonic and photonic applications in fields such as health care (imaging and sensing), energy efficient management (solid-state lighting, photovoltaics, and displays), and defense (solid-state lasers). Upconversion nanocrystals, which convert infrared into visible light, possess unique properties that make them highly desirable optical probes. However, for most of those crystals their implementation has been limited by their low brightness and reduced color tunability. This project focuses on establishing relationships between the chemical composition, atomic structure, and luminescence of upconversion nanocrystals with a view towards designing bright and color-tunable emitters. The project takes advantage of the versatility of a series of nanocrystals whose composition and atomic structure can be finely controlled, and is expected to expand the library of bright and multicolor upconverters, while also generating fundamental knowledge of light-matter interactions at the nanoscale. The project provides new opportunities to contribute to workforce development at both graduate and undergraduate levels. Graduate students are trained in the synthesis and advanced characterization of luminescent nanomaterials. Educational activities are developed to integrate scientific research into undergraduate education through Wayne State University's Nanoengineering Undergraduate Certificate Program.

Technical description: Upconversion nanocrystals offer several potential advantages over molecular downconversion fluorophores traditionally employed in biophotonic applications such as optical imaging and sensing. However, their implementation as optical probes has been limited by their low efficiency and lack of full-spectrum color tunability. An ongoing challenge in the field of upconverting nanocrystals is the rational design of efficient and color-tunable emitters via manipulation of the chemical composition and crystal structure. This project utilizes a series of chemically flexible nanomaterials to enable compositional control of structural features directly involved in energy-transfer processes relevant to light upconversion. The goal is to establish a series of crystallochemical principles that create the basis for the rational design of upconverting nanocrystals with optimized energy-transfer pathways through a systematic analysis of composition-structure-luminescence relationships. This project involves solution-phase synthesis of colloidal nanocrystals with controlled chemical composition and size, evaluation of their crystal structure using a combination of multiple spectroscopic techniques (X-ray diffraction, X-ray total scattering, and X-ray absorption), and thorough study of their light upconversion properties using spectrofluorometry (steady-state and time-dependent).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Upconverting nanocrystals, which sequentially absorb near-infrared photons and emit higher-energy visible photons, offer several advantages over molecular downconversion fluorophores employed in biophotonics. Among these advantages are the ability to achieve excitation and emission within the first biological window of optical transparency (600–1300 nm). However, implementation of upconverting nanocrystals as luminescent thermometers has been hindered by the limited ability to design materials that display high luminescence efficiency and adequate color-tunability. Identifying ways to utilize chemical composition and crystal structure to direct the flow of energy creates the opportunity to bridge this gap.

 

With the support of NSF, our research group has developed a new family of luminescence nanomaterials for biosensing purposes. Significant results included:

 

(1) new chemistries to access lanthanide-doped mixed-halide nanocrystals. Synthetic developments were motivated by the absence of solution-phase routes to lanthanide-doped alkaline-earth fluorohalide nanocrystals (MFX; M = Ca, Sr, Ba; X = Cl, Br, I). Our group bridged that gap by using pairs of trihaloacetic acids (e.g., CF3COOH–CX3COOH) to create metal–organic precursors whose solution thermolysis affords fluorohalide nanocrystals.

 

(2) the demonstration that color-tunability across the family of alkaline-earth fluorohalide nanocrystals can be achieved using two synthetic levers: (i) the chemical composition of the host, and (ii) the concentration of sensitizer–activator pairs.

 

(3) a systematic approach to probe the atomic arrangement of luminescent nanocrystals. Characterizing the structure of nanomaterials is inherently challenging because bulk models break down due to reduced structural coherence. We demonstrated that this challenge can be tackled by interrogating atomic correlations in short, intermediate, and long distances. 

 

(4) the demonstration that quantitative information about the distribution of Er3+ activators in alkaline-earth fluorohalide nanocrystals and their photophysical behavior can be gained via temperature-dependent and time-resolved photoluminescence measurements. This information revealed the potential of rare-earth-doped alkaline-earth fluorohalide nanocrystals as luminescence temperature sensors (i.e., thermosensitive nanophosphors).

 

These results impacted both the disciplines of photonic materials and materials chemistry by (1) providing synthetic access to a novel family of color-tunable upconverting nanocrystals, (2) uncovering the effect of chemical composition and crystal structure on energy transfer processes that govern light upconversion at the nanoscale, (3) establishing relevant photophysical parameters for a new family of light upconverters, and (4) revealing the potential of this family of materials in biophotonics applications such as optical temperature sensing. Additionally, our results directly impact the field of condensed matter. Indeed, establishing the principles that govern light upconversion at the nanoscale is critical to enable the design of novel upconverting materials for use in health (bioimaging and biosensing) and defense (solid-state lasers) applications.

 

Eight peer-reviewed articles totally or partially supported by this Award were published over the course of the four-year period of the Award. These were published in Chemistry of Materials, Inorganic Chemistry, Dalton Transactions, and Journal of Luminescence. Graduate students supported by this Award presented posters at national and regional conferences including the MRS Spring Meeting and Exhibit, the ACS National Meeting, the ACS Central Regional Meeting, and The Ohio Inorganic Weekend. The principal investigator gave research seminars at over 20 institutions, including research universities and primarily undergraduate institutions.

 

This Award provided opportunities for training and professional development of five chemistry graduate students (Ms. Tauni Dissanayake, Ms. Dulani Dhanapala, Mr. Dinesh Amarasinghe, Ms. Hashini Munasinghe, and Mr. Hermeson Benicio) and four (Ms. Natalie Mannino, Ms. Laura Mendoza, Ms. Emily Yatooma, and Ms. Ci Lee). Graduate students were trained in inert atmosphere Schlenk line synthesis and manipulations, solution-based nanocrystal synthesis, powder X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, quantitative crystal structure analysis (Rietveld, pair distribution function, XANES/XAFS), and steady-state, time-dependent, and variable-temperature photoluminescence. Ms. Dhanapala, Mr. Amarasinghe, and Ms. Munasinghe also had the opportunity to perform on-site experiments at the Advanced Photon Source of Argonne National Laboratory. Graduate students also developed their oral presentation and manuscript writing skills. Dr. Tauni Dissanayake graduated in September 2019 and is now a Research Scientist at AhuraTech, a nanomaterials manufacturing company located in Brighton (Michigan). Dr. Dinesh Amarasinghe graduated in October 2020 and is now a postdoctoral research associate at Iowa State University. Undergraduates B.Sc. Natalie Mannino, B.Sc. Laura Mendoza, and B.A. Emily Yatooma graduated in 2016, 2017, and 2020, respectively, and coauthored peer-reviewed articles prior to graduation. These manuscripts acknowledge this Award (DMR-1606917).

 

Other educational and outreach activities developed in the context of this Award included:

 

(1) curriculum development. Dr. Rabuffetti implemented a series of activities that integrate scientific research in the field of upconverting nanomaterials into undergraduate education. These were first incorporated into the Nanoengineering Undergraduate Certificate Program sponsored by NSF between 2013 and 2018 (EEC–1343703) and are now part of CHE5995 (Introduction to Nanomaterials and Nanoscience for Chemical Engineers).

 

(2) K-12 outreach. Outreach activities consisted of annual laboratory tours for 40 students belonging to Western International High School and Cesar Chavez Academy; both schools serve the Latino population of Detroit’s Mexicantown (>75% Hispanic students).
